newsitem.title: UK: Gold eyes U.S. rate change, others becalmed pre Christmas.
newsitem.headline: Gold eyes U.S. rate change, others becalmed pre Christmas.

text.p: Gold ticked higher on Tuesday on the back of weaker stock market and coffee lost some ground but other commodity markets were becalmed ahead of the holidays.

Copper's price slide from six-month highs hit last month accelerated this week and more volatility is expected as the market seeks direction after the shockwaves from the Sumitomo scandal earlier this year.
Gold was fixed at $368.95 an ounce against Monday's $367.55 after a stronger-than-expected U.S. housing starts data depressed U.S. bond and share prices.
The data jangled market nerves over interest rate hike prospects.
Although the U.S. Federal Reserve is not expected to move on interest rates after Tuesday's regular Federal Open market Committee, some economists fear a rate hike could come early next year.
But generally, investors continued to stay away from gold.
"It would take something extraordinary to move the gold market," said one. "By now 50-point movments on Wall Street are run of the mill."
As with other commodities, gold market activity is slowing down ahead of Christmas and the New Year.
"Everything's winding down for Christmas. There's not much interbank trading and I can't see anything significant happening," another trader said.
In coffee, London prices lost about two percent at one stage on origin selling. But they ended with pared losses on reports a cold airmass was threatening the Mexican coffee belt.
In base metals, copper see-sawed around $2,100 a tonne on the London Metal Exchange after a more bullish than expected stock report shook the market as it approached the slow holiday period.
Overall, the metal has given up $200 from its peak in late November, the highest since Sumitomo Corp uncovered billions of dollars in losses in June, sending prices crashing.
The year's high was hit in May at around $2,700 per tonne.
"I think you'd have to expect more volatility...There's no indication that it won't flare up again," said analyst Robin Bahr of broker Brandeis.
LME copper stocks have edged up to 115,375 tonnes, up slightly from a 6-1/4 year low hit in late November, but still under half the 275,775 tonnes in September.
Some leading commodity prices at 1744 GMT
Tuesday Monday
